dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, have you heard about Returnly? Like, this company trying to tackle payment delays for returns?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, have you heard about Returnly? Like, this company trying to tackle payment delays for returns?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! The one that gives you immediate store credit, right? Even before you, like, ship the item back sometimes? That's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! The one that gives you immediate store credit, right? Even before you, like, ship the item back sometimes? That's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item. The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They're, uh, based out of San Francisco, and they claim they can give 85% of customers instant credit just by assessing their risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They're, uh, based out of San Francisco, and they claim they can give eighty five percent of customers instant credit just by assessing their risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item. The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's pretty smart. And they just, like, [interrupts] raised a bunch of money too, didn't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's pretty smart. And they just, like, raised a bunch of money too, didn't they?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they did! $19 million in a Series B round, bringing their total funding up to $30 million. Craft Ventures led it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they did! nineteen million dollars in a Series B round, bringing their total funding up to thirty million dollars. Craft Ventures led it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm. This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's a serious chunk of change. So, what's their, uh, big success story so far?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's a serious chunk of change. So, what's their, uh, big success story so far?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article mentions this first return they ever processed. It was a customer who spent 75 bucks on lipstick, but, like, got the wrong shade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article mentions this first return they ever processed. It was a customer who spent seventy five bucks on lipstick, but, like, got the wrong shade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first return it processed came from a customer who spent $75 on foundation, sight unseen, and wound up with the wrong shade for her skin tone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, classic online shopping problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, classic online shopping problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, she got the immediate store credit, bought a foundation in a different shade, and then, surprisingly, also added a *different* lipstick to her order.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, she got the immediate store credit, bought a foundation in a different shade, and then, surprisingly, also added a different lipstick to her order.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: She was issued instant store credit, which she then used to buy the foundation in a different shade, in addition to throwing in a lipstick.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: See! That's what you'd expect! You get the credit, you spend it, and then some. It's like, a win-win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: See! That's what you'd expect! You get the credit, you spend it, and then some. It's like, a win-win.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's the interesting twist. Returnly *hopes* you'll spend more, but, uh, it turns out their customers are actually spending *less*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's the interesting twist. Returnly hopes you'll spend more, but, uh, it turns out their customers are actually spending less.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? That's totally counter-intuitive!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? That's totally counter-intuitive!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! Nine out of ten order a second item, but they underspend the original order size by, like, 23 percent. The CEO even said, "consumers end up buying less."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! Nine out of ten order a second item, but they underspend the original order size by, like, twenty three percent. The C E O even said, consumers end up buying less.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says. Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%. When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, the retailer loses a revenue opportunity, but the customer gets instant gratification. It's, uh, a trade-off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, the retailer loses a revenue opportunity, but the customer gets instant gratification. It's, uh, a trade-off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it really highlights the huge problem of online returns, right? Like, they're twice as likely to be returned than in-store purchases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it really highlights the huge problem of online returns, right? Like, they're twice as likely to be returned than in-store purchases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Online purchases are three times more likely to be returned than those made in a physical store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, over a hundred billion dollars in returns in 2017 alone. It's a massive issue for e-commerce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, over a hundred billion dollars in returns in twenty seventeen alone. It's a massive issue for e-commerce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, over $100 billion of items that were purchased online were returned, according to the U.S. Postal Services Office of Inspector General.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Returnly profits by taking a cut of transactions and, uh, charging merchants an annual subscription fee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Returnly profits by taking a cut of transactions and, uh, charging merchants an annual subscription fee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And they rely on data from their network to assess risk, right? Like, to decide whether to give you that instant credit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they rely on data from their network to assess risk, right? Like, to decide whether to give you that instant credit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In order to extend store credit the way that it does, it depends on data from its merchant network to assess a shoppers risk. This essentially means it analyzes a consumers past shopping activity at the retailers that it works with to make a decision.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's all about that network effect. And they even assume the risk if, like, an item never gets returned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's all about that network effect. And they even assume the risk if, like, an item never gets returned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly then assumes the risk that a product is never returned, whether thats because a customer fails to ship it back in the first place, it arrives damaged or it gets lost in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously? What do they do then? Just, uh, hope for the best?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously? What do they do then? Just, uh, hope for the best?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they can choose to just ignore it, or they might, like, nudge the customer with an email or make it easier by sending a printed label or scheduling a pickup. Pretty flexible, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they can choose to just ignore it, or they might, like, nudge the customer with an email or make it easier by sending a printed label or scheduling a pickup. Pretty flexible, actually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.
